message: I think that really adds a lot to the experience
They wanted full outfit customization, dozens of assets and animations on screen, leaderboards, AI for single player and async mode, and online multiplayer
Speakers are Juan Gril & Pablo Testa, Joju Games
Basically they wanted to make an RTS that anyone can play
They start with the player outline, then do the base color and fill it in
It's a distributed team, they use Skype and Google Docs to collaborate
For the AI they brainstorm, implement, playtest, tweak, and loop until it feels polished.
I like that whole ability to see your friends faces on the leaderboard
Mochi integration was apparently a big timesaver, since social network implementation was transparent across social networks.
Answer to audience question: They use player.io and haven't looked into peer-to-peer multiplayer.
In coming up with AI players, first they started with a narrative, then filled that in with an algorithm
Very cool, they mark all their strings for localization
The snowboarder output was the most popular one, and the bunny outfit was the least popular.  They built a tracking system, and then just focused on the sporty looks.
